heroes.name: David Pearce
heroes.shortIntro: Negative-utilitarian transhumanist philosopher. Author of "The Hedonistic Imperative" and "The Abolitionist Project". Co-founder of Humanity+ (back then the World Transhumanist Association).
heroes.what: Popularized suffering-focused ethics and the notion of "paradise engineering" within transhumanist movement. Argues for technological solutions to abolish suffering for all sentient beings. Authored The Anti-Speciesist Revolution.
quotes: [...] both natural selection and the historical record offer powerful reasons for doubting the trustworthiness of our naive moral intuitions. So the possibility that human civilisation might be founded upon some monstrous evil should be taken seriously - even if the possibility seems transparently absurd at the time.

heroes.name: Michael Greger
heroes.shortIntro: Physician, dietician, professional speaker, writer. Advocates whole-food, plant-based diets. A person behind NutritionFacts.org.
heroes.what: A prolific educator on whole-food, plant-based diets and health harms of eating animals. In his videos and articles on NutritionFacts.org, Greger briefly presents (with his signature touch of humor!) scientific studies relevant to a healthy lifestyle. The site claims, "100% of all proceeds he has ever received from his books, DVDs, and speaking engagements has always and will always be donated to charity."

heroes.name: Matt Ball
heroes.shortIntro: Co-founder and past Executive Director of Vegan Outreach. Director of Engagement and Outreach at Farm Sanctuary. Co-authored "The Animal Activist's Handbook". Author of "The Accidental Activist".
heroes.what: Matt has been an inspiration for effective animal activists for more than 20 years. In 1993, together with Jack Norris, Matt co-founded Vegan Outreach, a famous, standout charity promoting vegan ethics. Today he continues his work on reducing human-caused animal suffering by devoting his time to Farm Sanctuary and writing.
quotes: The single most important lesson I’ve learned in the past twenty years is that the irreducible heart of what matters is suffering. Back then, even though I was absolutely sure I knew everything, I really didn’t know anything about suffering. Since then, though, I’ve developed a chronic disease and experienced times when I thought I was going to die, times when I wished I would die. Back then, I worried about abstractions and words and principles; I argued about exploitation, oppression, liberation. I didn’t take suffering seriously. Now, knowing what suffering really is, and knowing how much there is in the world, all my previous concerns seem, well . . . to put it kindly . . . ridiculous.
Veganism is important, not as an end in itself, but as a powerful tool for opposing the horrors of factory farms and industrial slaughterhouses.

heroes.name: Brian Tomasik
heroes.shortIntro: Person behind Essays On Reducing Suffering. Argues for moral urgency of wild-animal suffering and caution towards digital sentience. Co-founder of and researcher at the Foundational Research Institute.
heroes.what: Brian's persuasive and clear argumentation, scientific rigor, and honesty make him a very contagious thinker; at least once you become accustomed with unconventional ideas he deals with -- from earn-to-give effective altruism and wild-animal suffering to insect and digital sentience. Brian's overarching concern is suffering reduction. After pursuing earn-to-give strategy working on Microsoft's Bing, he co-founded the Foundational Research Institute, 'a charity that explores the best ways to reduce suffering in the future'. He also argues for contributing to Wikipedia on social sciences and is a contributor himself.
quotes: Suffering is always experienced in earnest, whether inflicted in sport, on a factory farm, or in the wild. Nature isn't an abstraction. It's not a laboratory, tourist attraction, or metaphor. Is animal suffering acceptable, given that billions experience it in earnest?

heroes.name: Oscar Horta
heroes.shortIntro: Antispeciesist activist. Co-founder of Animal Ethics. Argues for interventions in wild nature in the interest of animals. Logic and moral philosophy prof. at the University of Santiago de Compostela.
heroes.what: An influential thinker on issues of speciesism and prevailing disvalue in wild nature. Challenges environmentalism on the grounds that it puts abstract concepts, like 'healthy' ecosystems and number of species, above wellbeing of sentient individuals. Besides academic writing and lecturing, Oscar gives public talks and develops Animal Ethics, a standout charity that 'works to spread anti-speciesist messages in academia and to a general audience'. Many of Horta's works are in Spanish.

heroes.name: Melanie Joy
heroes.shortIntro: Social psychologist and vegan activist. Popularized the term carnism. Wrote Why We Love Dogs, Eat Pigs, and Wear Cows. Founder and president of Beyond Carnism.
heroes.what: Melanie Joy is a Harvard-educated PhD psychologist, writer, and vegan activist. She is perhaps best known for the term carnism, 'the invisible belief system that shapes our perception of the meat, eggs, and dairy we eat, so that we love some animals and eat others' without noticing the paradox. Although coined in 2001, the concept caught on after her 2009 book Why We Love Dogs, Eat Pigs, and Wear Cows and got major public exposure by her TEDx talk Toward Rational, Authentic Food Choices. Melanie also authored "Strategic Action for Animals" and was awarded the Institute of Jainology's Ahimsa Award for promoting non-violence principles.
quotes: There is a vast mythology surrounding meat, but all the myths are in one way or another related to what I refer to as the Three Ns of Justification: eating meat is normal, natural, and necessary. The Three Ns have been invoked to justify all exploitative systems, from African slavery to the Nazi Holocaust. When an ideology is in its prime, these myths rarely come under scrutiny. However, when the system finally collapses, the Three Ns are recognized as ludicrous.
